entry.title: SAP Screen Personas in the Default Installation Stack of SAP S/4HANA 2025, Private Cloud Edition
entry.content:
Implications for Greenfield Installations

For new SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition customers, this change ensures a simplified and accelerated setup experience.

With SAP Screen Personas pre-installed:

  • Customers gain immediate access to screen personalization and simplification capabilities.

  • The installation and configuration process is significantly simplified, reducing both time and effort.

This enhancement underscores SAP‚Äôs commitment to delivering a seamless and user-centric onboarding experience for S/4HANA customers.

Impact on Existing Installations

For existing SAP Screen Personas customers, the transition to SAP S/4HANA 2025 is expected to be smooth and non-disruptive.

  • If the currently installed SAP Screen Personas add-on version is compatible with SAP S/4HANA 2025, it can be retained and used without modification.

  • If the existing version is not compatible, a manual upgrade of the add-on must be completed prior to installing SAP S/4HANA 2025.

Future FPS Upgrades

When a new Feature Pack Stack (FPS) becomes available for SAP S/4HANA 2025, Private Cloud Edition, it will include the latest available Support Package (SP) of SAP Screen Personas at that time.

Support Package Release Strategy or SAP Screen Personas.

There is no change to the existing Support Package (SP) release strategy for SAP Screen Personas.

  • SAP will continue to deliver annual Support Package releases , providing regular enhancements and maintenance updates.
  • Customers may choose to upgrade to newer Support Packages as they become available.

This continuity ensures customers can plan their upgrades in alignment with their broader S/4HANA lifecycle strategy. Please refer to note 2013453 for more details.

Summary

With SAP Screen Personas now included as part of the default SAP S/4HANA 2025, Private Cloud Edition installation stack, customers benefit from an even more integrated and efficient user experience.

This change eliminates the need for separate installation steps and reinforces SAP‚Äôs ongoing focus on delivering streamlined, intuitive, and adaptable user experiences within the S/4HANA environment.

Further Reading:
  • SAP Screen Personas
  • Getting Started with UI Adaptations for Classic Applications in SAP S/4HANA Cloud

Learn more about SAP Screen Personas:

  • Online training. The best way to learn the basics about SAP Screen Personas (Adapt UI for classic applications) is to take our free training course on the learning.sap.com platform: https://learning.sap.com/courses/adapting-the-ui-in-sap-s-4hana-cloud-using-sap-screen-personas
  • Connect with your peers. Every other month, we have a group of customers that gather online to share best practices, demo their flavors, and answer each other‚Äôs questions. Experts from the product team also join to explain how to use the latest functionality. If you are interested in joining, you can sign up online to join the SAP Screen Personas practitioner forum. This will add you to the mailing list for the monthly meeting summaries. Please contact ‚ÄúPeter Spielvogel‚Äú or me directly if you want to join the monthly calls.
  • Product documentation. The SAP Screen Personas documentation, recently updated to be even more clear and comprehensive, contains the latest information about the product.

Going forward with SAP Screen Personas

If you are not currently using SAP Screen Personas, why not?

Worried that we won‚Äôt support it into the future? Don‚Äôt be.  We are supporting SAP Screen Personas functionality through at least 2040.

Have other concerns about the roadmap for SAP Screen Personas? See if we answer them in our latest roadmap blog post.

entry.title: Re: PPF update from EWM to ERP problem
entry.content:
Hi Blendi Hoxha,
Of course, it's a configuration issue related to newly added warehouse number, you must verify the integration setting between EWM and ERP for new warehouse.

Following can be the possible causes are mentioned below.
Missing or incorrect number range configuration: If the number range for delivery documents (e.g., 9566) is not maintained for the new warehouse, ERP won't recognize the inbound delivery updates.

PPF action not triggering ERP update: The ‚ÄúSend ERP Delivery Messages‚Äù PPF might not be executing properly for the new warehouse. It could be stuck in yellow status or timing out.

Inbound queue issues: The delivery update might be stuck in the inbound queue (transaction SMQ2) due to missing configuration or errors in the queue processing.

Warehouse-specific integration settings: The new warehouse might not be fully integrated with ERP. This includes missing entries in the warehouse-specific customizing tables for delivery processing, queue management, and partner profiles

Please follow these steps to resolve the issue.

Check PPF Action Execution
Go to the inbound delivery in EWM and verify if the ‚ÄúSend ERP Delivery Messages‚Äù PPF action executed successfully. If it‚Äôs in yellow or error status, try reprocessing it manually and check for dumps or timeouts.

Inspect Inbound Queues
Use transaction SMQ2 to check if the delivery update is stuck. Look for entries related to the delivery document and analyze the error logs.

Verify Number Range Configuration
Use transaction SNRO to check if number ranges (e.g., for delivery document type 9566) are maintained for the current year and warehouse. Maintain missing intervals if needed.

Review Warehouse Integration Settings
Ensure the new warehouse is correctly assigned in the integration model.
Check customizing in (/SCWM/ERP_WAREHOUSE, /SCWM/WHR, Partner profiles (WE20) for IDoc communication,
Queue settings for delivery updates )

Test with a Known Working Warehouse
Compare the configuration of the new warehouse with one that works correctly. Look for discrepancies in delivery types, queue settings, and PPF actions.


Hope this will resolve your issue

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Subcontracting with MRP Area: material reserv...
entry.content:
Hi Giovanni,
As you explain its correct everyone will expect immediate updates to transfer requirements, but SAP S/4HANA's subcontracting flow with MRP Areas has a known limitation, movement 541 does not automatically reduce transfer requirements until the next MRP Live run.

To mitigate this issue, you can follow below mention best practices.
1. Schedule MRP Live (MD01N) more frequently, especially after major subcontracting movements.
2. Consider using BAdIs or custom logic to trigger MRP Live or refresh MD04 views post-541 movement.
3. Use transaction MDAB (Regenerative Planning) or MDRE (Reorganization of Planning File Entries) if you want to force updates outside of MD01N.
4. Explore SAP Notes or OSS messages for enhancements or patches that may address this behavior.

It‚Äôs a standard behavior in S/4HANA with MRP Areas. SAP has not yet provided a native solution to auto-update transfer requirements post-541


https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/s-4hana-subcontracting-with-mrp-area/ba-p/13421838

entry.title: A Workaround to Display Current and Future Leave Balances on the TimeOff Request Page
entry.content:
This post introduces a practical workaround to display both current and future leave balances simultaneously on the Time Off Application page in SAP SuccessFactors. The solution originated from a real-world business requirement where the standard system configuration was insufficient. By adding a custom field and an auto-calculation business rule, we can fulfill this need effectively.

Background

The business requirement was to provide employees with visibility of:

  • Current leave balance as of the application date.
  • Future leave balance as of the time account end date.

This allows employees to make informed decisions when submitting leave requests. However, displaying the future balance only on the Time Account page was not considered user-friendly, as it required navigating to a separate view.

Known Limitation

In the standard configuration, only the balance as of the application date can be displayed. Even though you can adjust the Balance Calculation Setting in Manage Data > Time Type to consider future leave postings, the system does not provide an additional standard field to show both balances simultaneously.

Workaround Solution

1. Add a Custom Read-Only Conditional Field ‚Äì ‚ÄúFuture Balance‚Äù

Create a custom field named Future Balance within the Time Off submission form.
This field will display the calculated future balance. Note the following considerations:

  • The custom field will always appear below the standard fields in the UI. If additional fields such as attachments are present, employees may need to scroll down to view it.
  • The field can be configured as conditional, meaning it appears only for specific leave types.
  • Although SAP has recently updated the attachment field‚Äôs UI in the latest Edit Profile interface, this improvement is not yet applied to the Time Off page in the current release.

2. Configure a Business Rule to Auto-Populate the Future Balance

In the standard MDF object EmployeeTime, create a business rule that automatically calculates and populates the value for the Future Balance field. This rule should trigger on change of relevant fields (e.g., Time Type, Start Date, End Date).

Key implementation notes:

  1. The rule should not be created under the Time Type Validation Rule section, as that configuration triggers only upon saving or submitting the request ‚Äî not during field change events.
  2. When calculating the future balance, the system automatically includes pending approvals and future accruals. This behavior cannot be modified and follows SAP‚Äôs standard calculation logic as documented here:
    Calculate Balance for Types ‚Äì SAP Help Portal

Summary

Due to standard system limitations, implementing both current and future leave balance display on the Time Off Application page requires a workaround using:

  • A custom read-only field to store the future balance.
  • A business rule to calculate and populate the value dynamically.

While this approach meets the requirement, it still carries certain constraints:

  • Accrual simulation is limited by business rule functionality.
  • UI layout limitations prevent displaying both balances in a fully consolidated view.

It is recommended that SAP further optimize the Time Off and Attachment UI to better support these common business needs in future releases.

entry.title: Re: Auto Clear EBS Invoices Need to be Cleared
entry.content:
Hi Goody,
If you want to enable auto clearing using the invoice number in the XREF2_HD field, you need to customize the clearing criteria in transaction OB74 to include XREF2_HD instead of‚Äîor in addition to‚ÄîXBLNR.

Following are the steps to Enable Auto Clearing via XREF2_HD
Use Transaction OB74 (Define Clearing Criteria), Go to transaction OB74. Create or modify a clearing variant. In the criteria list, add XREF2_HD (Reference Key 2) as one of the fields. You can include other fields like company code, document type, amount, etc., depending on your matching logic.

Ensure Field Population During Posting, Confirm that XREF2_HD is consistently populated during invoice and payment postings. This may require customizing your posting logic or user exits (e.g., via BAPI or BADI) to ensure the field is filled correctly.


Run F.13 for Auto Clearing, Execute transaction F.13 with the appropriate parameters. Make sure the variant used includes the updated OB74 configuration.

Test with Sample Documents, Post sample invoices and payments with matching values in XREF2_HD.
Run F.13 and verify that clearing occurs as expected.

You must also consider the following point mentioned below

  • Field Availability: If XREF2_HD isn‚Äôt visible during document entry, you may need to enhance the screen layout or use BADI FAGL_BADI_POSTING to populate it programmatically. 
  • Consistency: Ensure both sides of the transaction (invoice and payment) use the same format and value in XREF2_HD. 
  • Fallback Strategy: If XBLNR is still needed for other processes, consider using both fields in OB74 to broaden matching criteria.

Hope this will help you. if so please confirm

entry.title: Re: Clock‚ÄØIn‚ÄØClock Out in SAP SuccessFactors‚ÄØTime Tracking ‚Äì Overview and How-To Guide
entry.content:
@ManonH  - There are two ways to indicate that a time event is not paired.

1. Enable Pairing of Time Events of same Time Event Type in Configure Clock In Clock Out - Settings

If this Time Event Pairing settings is not enabled, then the clock in will not pair with the clock in on Tuesday.

2. Overdue Time Events

The overdue time events can be set with a duration which is lesser than 24 hours and this highlights that a time event is not paired after the certain number of hours mentioned in the Duration is elapsed. It would alert on Monday evening that Clock Out was not punched.

If the time event on Tuesday is before 24 hours, we pair the time event with Monday as we support cross midnight. We have in roadmap to support cross midnight pairing only when the time profile has cross midnight set to "Yes". Currently, this pairs over midnight already.

For the second question on the Manager seeing these alerts, the Manage Clock In Clock Out is a target population-based page. This means, a manager can only see his direct report information in this page when such a permission is configured. Manage Clock In Clock Out shows the pairing errors and can be set up for a Manager as well.

Regards
Neetha

entry.title: Re: Reset password email sent every day
entry.content: Hi, That definitely sounds like someone (or some bot) is trying to brute-force your IAS account. The IP you mentioned (3.124.174.204) belongs to AWS, so it‚Äôs likely an automated login attempt rather than a person. I‚Äôd recommend: Enabling MFA (multi-factor authentication) if you haven‚Äôt already ‚Äî it will stop unauthorized access even if someone guesses your password. Reset your password and use a strong, unique one. Open a SAP support ticket with the IP details ‚Äî they can block or throttle repeated failed attempts from that address. You‚Äôre doing the right thing keeping an eye on those IAS notifications. üëç

entry.title: Re: Sales oder created with wrong time slot
entry.content:
In SAP EDI-based order creation with ORDERS and ORDERS05, the delivery date and time are usually mapped from segments like:

  • E1EDP20 ‚Üí Delivery schedule
  • E1EDP20-EDATU ‚Üí Delivery date
  • E1EDP20-ETZU ‚Üí Delivery time

So go to transaction WE02 or WE05 to inspect the inbound IDoc. Confirm that multiple E1EDP20 segments exist with different ETZU values for the same EDATU

entry.title: Predicting Cycling Performance: SAP RPT-1 vs AI Chat Models and Strava
entry.content:
Executive Summary

This study compares the prediction accuracy of SAP RPT-1, Strava, and leading AI chat models (Copilot, ChatGPT, Gemini) for a real cycling route. Using historical data from 85 rides, each model predicted time and average speed for the next session. Results show that SAP RPT-1 delivered highly accurate, deterministic forecasts, outperforming general-purpose LLMs and coming close to Strava‚Äôs specialized algorithm. These findings highlight SAP RPT-1‚Äôs potential for precise forecasting in structured data scenarios. Once the model reaches General Availability, we will extend this analysis to real business datasets for even more impactful insights.

 

This article was created with the support of Microsoft Copilot, but the results are based on a real-world experience.

Introduction

Predicting performance in cycling is not just a sports challenge - it‚Äôs a fascinating analogy for forecasting in business. Just like companies predict production or maintenance needs, cyclists can try to anticipate their next ride‚Äôs time and average speed. In this study, we explored how different prediction models perform when estimating these metrics for a real cycling route.

We compared five approaches:

  • Strava‚Äôs prediction engine, widely trusted by athletes.
  • SAP RPT-1, a tabular model designed for structured data.
  • Three popular AI chat models: Microsoft Copilot, ChatGPT, and Gemini.
  • The actual ride result, serving as the baseline.

The goal was simple: predict the route time and average speed as accurately as possible.

Methodology

The dataset included 85 cycling routes recorded over four months, covering distances, times, speeds, and elevation:

Each model received the same prompt:

‚ÄúI will give you a CSV file with all the data about my last 4 months with the bike. You should predict my route time and average speed during the route on the next Sunday. Label [PREDICT] identifies which data need to be predicted by you. Analyse and give me your expectations for this Sunday.‚Äù

We then compared:

  • Predicted time (in seconds)
  • Average speed (in km/h)
  • Response time (how fast the model delivered its prediction)

Finally, we benchmarked these predictions against the real ride, which covered 53.6 km with 765 m elevation.

Results

The predictions from each model were compared against the actual ride, which covered 53.6 km with 765 m elevation. The key metrics analyzed were time (in seconds) and average speed (in km/h).

The simplified comparison shows clear differences in accuracy:

  • Strava delivered the closest prediction to reality, with only minor deviations in time and speed.
  • SAP RPT-1 performed impressively, producing deterministic results and staying very close to the real values.
  • Gemini was fast and understood units correctly, but its speed prediction deviated more than others.
  • Copilot struggled with consistency and unit interpretation, leading to larger errors.
  • ChatGPT showed the biggest gap, especially in time prediction, due to misinterpretation of units.

These results underline the importance of structured models like SAP RPT-1 for numeric predictions and reveal the limitations of general-purpose LLMs when handling precise, unit-based data.

Conclusions

The comparison highlights clear patterns:

  • Strava remains the most accurate overall, with minimal deviation in both time and speed. Its specialized algorithm and access to large datasets give it a strong advantage.
  • SAP RPT-1 stands out as a powerful alternative. It delivered deterministic predictions, handled structured data effectively, and achieved results very close to reality. This shows its potential for numeric forecasting beyond sports‚Äîthink production planning or predictive maintenance.
  • Gemini produced fast responses and understood units correctly, but its speed prediction was less precise.
  • Copilot and ChatGPT struggled with numeric interpretation. Copilot showed inconsistent outputs, while ChatGPT had the largest error in time prediction, likely due to misunderstanding units.

The charts you will include (bar chart, dispersion plot, and error chart) reinforce these insights, showing how SAP RPT-1 consistently outperforms general-purpose LLMs in accuracy and stability.

  • Bar charts reveal how predicted times and speeds compare to actual values.

  • Dispersion plots show the spread of speed predictions across models.

  • Error charts make deviations in time and speed crystal clear.

Key takeaway:
SAP RPT-1 has demonstrated a clear advantage over current LLM models by effectively leveraging structured data to deliver more accurate forecasts. Once the model reaches General Availability, we will be able to perform even more precise comparisons using real business datasets, unlocking its full potential for enterprise forecasting scenarios.

Annexes

To provide full transparency and context, this section includes screenshots of the responses generated by each model during the experiment. These captures show the raw outputs based on the same prompt and dataset, highlighting differences in interpretation, numeric handling, and prediction logic.
